newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Canberra committed to sell one-third Telstra.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Canberra committed to sell one-third Telstra.

text.p: Australian Communications Minister Richard Alston said on Monday the government was committed to sell only one-third of state-owned telecommunications carrier Telstra Corp in its first term.
"Our policy position is quite clear," Alston told parliament's upper house, the Senate. "We are committed to selling one third of Telstra and no more."
"The coalition (government) will offer by way of a share float, if necessary in two tranches depending on market conditions, one-third of the Commonwealth's equity in Telstra," Alston said.
The government's plan to sell one-third of Telstra for about A$8 billion requires approval by the Senate, where the government does not have a majority.
Prime Minister John Howard's Liberal-National government needs the support of at least two non-government senators to pass legislation.
The Labor opposition and minor parties holding the Senate balance of power have pledged to vote against the sell-off.
The government hopes to gain the support of the two independent senators, Mal Colston and Brian Harradine.
